<https://twitter.com/loicaroyer|@loicaroyer>: The latest version of #numpy (1.20) has some very exciting features! Finally #types! and more speed with SIMD support!

Congrats <https://twitter.com/numpy_team|@numpy_team> ! <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EyaVGvqUcAM3-aX.png>
attachments.text:
The latest version of #numpy (1.20) has some very exciting features! Finally #types! and more speed with SIMD support!

Congrats <https://twitter.com/numpy_team|@numpy_team> ! <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EyaVGvqUcAM3-aX.png>

text: Did a double take because I remembered seeing a 1.20 release announcement a few weeks back. Thankfully it's the same one :smile:

elements.text: Did a double take because I remembered seeing a 1.20 release announcement a few weeks back. Thankfully it's the same one

text: I just find it funny that people are getting excited about things like SIMD or typing in Numpy while we've been using it for a while now in Julia.

elements.text: I just find it funny that people are getting excited about things like SIMD or typing in Numpy while we've been using it for a while now in Julia.

text: Type annotations in Python still don‚Äôt do much.

elements.text: Type annotations in Python still don‚Äôt do much.

text:
I think they mean the underlying C code.
Make no mistake Numpy is fast. For instance, it will be interesting to compare `sin()` and `cos()` over an array.
